texts.value: G-protein coupled receptor for 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) (PubMed:2140514, PubMed:2156831). Also functions as a receptor for various drugs and psychoactive substances (By similarity). Ligand binding causes a conformation change that triggers signaling via guanine nucleotide-binding proteins (G proteins) and modulates the activity of downstream effectors, such as adenylate cyclase (By similarity). HTR1A is coupled to G(i)/G(o) G alpha proteins and mediates inhibitory neurotransmission: signaling inhibits adenylate cyclase activity and activates a phosphatidylinositol-calcium second messenger system that regulates the release of Ca(2+) ions from intracellular stores (By similarity). Beta-arrestin family members regulate signaling by mediating both receptor desensitization and resensitization processes (By similarity)
G-protein coupled receptor activity is regulated by lipids: phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate increases HTR1A-mediated activity
Heterodimer; heterodimerizes with GPER1 (By similarity). Interacts with YIF1B (PubMed:18685031). Interacts with GPR39 and GALR1 (By similarity)
Detected in hypothalamus, mesencephalon, amygdala, medulla, thalamus, septum and hippocampus
Belongs to the G-protein coupled receptor 1 family. 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor subfamily. HTR1A sub-subfamily

features.description: DRY motif; important for ligand-induced conformation changes
NPxxY motif; important for ligand-induced conformation changes and signaling

citation.title: Cloning, functional expression, and mRNA tissue distribution of the rat 5-hydroxytryptamine1A receptor gene.
Role of cytochrome P450 in the control of the production of erythropoietin.
Serotonin receptor activation reduces calcium current in an acutely dissociated adult central neuron.
Targeting of the 5-HT1A serotonin receptor to neuronal dendrites is mediated by Yif1B.
